We join Dr. Bunch and the wider museum community in committing to a better future, one that we demand from each other, and we demand from ourselves.

Read Dr. Bunch's full statement ‚ûû https://t.co/vzYeTgaZHu (4/4)

At the National Museum of Women in the Arts, founded more than 30 years ago to redefine traditional histories of art that excluded women, we are committed to uplifting marginalized voices and promoting social change. There is no easy formula for achieving this change. (3/4)

state unequivocally that #BlackLivesMatter. To be lasting, change must happen at every level of society, and in every sphere, including the arts. Black women artists‚Äô work remains consistently overlooked and woefully undervalued in museum collections. We have far to go. (2/4)

We stand in solidarity with @SmithsonianSec Lonnie G. Bunch III and his May 31, 2020 statement related to violent attacks against Black people and the struggle to maintain our democracy. It is important to add our voices and use our platform to amplify his words, and (1/4)
